title: Prosject OPL3X2
content:
I'ts me again, whit a little crazy prosject, i have been able to use hardware that running 2 OPL3 chip at the same time.
By connecting a computer builded for recording, and a old Intel 133 MHZ whit dos and win3.11 , i can capture music from games like from Apogee.

The record prossesing is 96KHZ 32bit 4chn. And whil be bounced to wav, and will be relesed as mp3 48khz 32 bit sterio.

The story to make it running, whas quite "heavy spend in time"
i spend 14-15 hour to install and make a Dos 6.22 and Win3.11 up and running. after a while, the disk died, so i had to re-install everthing on a other disk. good it didnt tok 14 hours again, but only a few. [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-smile.gif[/img]
the next day i spend alot of time to optimize the output volume, and get the noise floor lowest as possible. and that whas a hard task as well. i had to adjust a balanse between 2 mixers on to different soundcard, and evertime i have to re-boot, beacuse its store saved configurations in Autoexec.bat.

anyways there is alot more annoying episodes i have had. but i'm too lazy to tell everting.

let's see what i can relese soon

Allow me to correct some of your spelling/grammar. [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-smile.gif[/img]

It's me again, with a crazy little project. I've been able to create hardware that runs two OPL3 chips at the same time.
By connecting it between an old Intel 133 Mhz with DOS and Windows 3.11 and a newer computer intended for recording, I can now capture music from games that play Adlib music.

The sound processing is 96KHZ 32bit 4chn. It records to a WAV file, but I'll release the files I make as 48Khz 32 bit stereo files.

content: Yes - and it's significant because firstly it's using the real hardware synth (so this is the reference source that Adplug, DOSBox, etc. are all trying to imitate as closely as possible) and secondly it's using two chips for synthesis, so you get a nice stereo effect that you don't normally hear with just one sound card.<font color="#EEF2EE">[url=http://www.shikadi.net/keenwiki/]KeenWiki[/url] | [url=http://www.shikadi.net/moddingwiki/]ModdingWiki[/url]</font>

title: Re: Prosject OPL3X2
content:
That's true, but most songs (like the Monster Bash ones you've got above) are only OPL2 tunes, so they only output mono sound, even when you play them on an OPL3 chip.

That's why Hocus Pocus sounds so much nicer on an OPL3 - it's one of the few games that *does* use both channels on an OPL3 chip, and for that you don't need two sound cards to get the stereo effect.

Although it would be interesting to hear what Hocus Pocus sounds like in four channels - it would be like a quad-mono sound, with all channels slightly out of phase. I wonder whether it would be possible for your ears to pick it out? If you try it, upload a four-channel Ogg file so we can have a listen.[url=http://www.shikadi.net/keenwiki/]KeenWiki[/url] | [url=http://www.shikadi.net/moddingwiki/]ModdingWiki[/url]

title: Re: Prosject OPL3X2
content:
The OPL tracks Batteryman uploaded aren't mono - he used one sound card for the left channel and a second sound card for the right channel. The beauty being that the OPL chips produce a slightly different sound each time you play audio through them, so when you have two cards running in tandem they each produce sound that's slightly out of phase to the other, producing a nice sounding stereo sound, even though they're only playing mono music.

The Hocus Pocus music is stereo yes, but when you play the GM version it doesn't have the same stereo effect that Batteryman's files have. My point was that if Monster Bash's mono music sounds good using this stereo effect, Hocus Pocus' stereo music should sound interesting in quadraphonic. (One stereo sound card for the front speakers and a second for the rear.)[url=http://www.shikadi.net/keenwiki/]KeenWiki[/url] | [url=http://www.shikadi.net/moddingwiki/]ModdingWiki[/url]

title: Re: Prosject OPL3X2
content: If you're after music quality then yes I agree, it doesn't sound as good through Adlib.  But I wasn't suggesting quadraphonic Adlib to make Hocus Pocus sound *better*, I was just curious to hear what quadraphonic Adlib would sound like - whether your ears would be able to notice any difference over stereo.  Hocus Pocus was just the first game that came to mind that uses out of phase stereo, so I only mentioned it since it would be an ideal candidate to generate quadraphonic sound with two sound cards - again, just to satisfy my curiosity as to how it might sound.<font color="#EEF2EE">[url=http://www.shikadi.net/keenwiki/]KeenWiki[/url] | [url=http://www.shikadi.net/moddingwiki/]ModdingWiki[/url]</font>
